lexUnit.definition: FN: a large group of sentients.

sentence.text: The slim , perfectly manicured , fingers touched her face and hair like a swarm of honeybees exploring a bed of exotic flowers .
A second swarm of enemies attacked Arthur 's skin and he swore at them blue murder .
Immediately a swarm of coolies rushed towards him , dragging their wire-wheeled rickshaws behind them , and he leaped into the nearest one with a loud whoop .
Such swarms are fed on by mysticete ( whalebone or baleen ) whales , and experienced whale hunters sought the swarms of krill in the expectation that whales would be seeking them too .
The ` Illustrious " had been subjected to vicious bombing only a short time previously , and the defending fighters had been battered by swarms of Me109s and Macchis .

Gradually there arose a faint humming from outside the tent as people gathered to talk and speculate , so it seemed as if those left inside were surrounded by a swarm of curious but not unfriendly bees .
Gungawatti , when frightened by a swarm of jungle bees , gave him his first ride on the back of a bolting elephant .
A SWARM of killer African bees attacked some 70 children on a school playground in a northern Mexico village , officials said .
The cow was bloated and a swarm of flies were already buzzing round it .
Swarms of flies and mosquitoes hover over the marshes .
She picked one , hoisting the bread under one arm , and swished it over her shoulder at the swarm of cattle flies that buzzed there .
The monastic continuator of the Croyland Chronicle wrote of the same events in hysterical terms ; the northern army moved south like a swarm of locusts , ravaging all that lay in its path .
But , before he had the chance to complete the sentence , a swarm of people came from out of the birch-trees and Aziz and Hasan disappeared into them .
They were joined by a swarm of spies of all conceivable nationalities , and Macau won a name for international intrigue .
